notes: Jessica Riskin explains: “If life was material, then matter was alive, and to see living creatures as machines was also to vivify machinery.” Riskin, “Eighteenth-Century Wetware,” p. 99. Read a PDF of Riskin’s article here.
Brandy Schillace, “Reproducing’ Custom: Mechanical Habits and Female Machines in Augustan Women’s Education” Feminist Formations, (Spring 2013): 25.1.
Ruth Perry, “The Veil of Chastity.” Sexuality in Eighteenth-Century Britain. (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1982), p. 147.

Mechanical automations of various sorts gained popularity in the eighteenth century as spectacle as well as science, from Jacques Vaucanson’s 1738 “flute-player,” a mechanical musician, to surgeon Claude-Nicolas Le Cat’s proposed ‘automaton man,’ a kind of phantom for demonstrating circulation. See Riskin, “Eighteenth-Century Wetware.”
R.W. Johnstone, William Smellie, The Master of British Midwifery (Edinburgh: E. & S. Livingstone LTD., 1952), p. 25.
William Theodore Brannt, India Rubber, gulta-percha, and balata. (Philadelphia: Henry Carey Baird and Company, 1900), pp. 2-3.
Helen King, Midwifery, Obstetrics and the Rise of Gynaecology: The Uses of a Sixteenth Century Compendium. (Burlington: Ashgate, 2007), p. 134.

Samuel Paterson, “A Catalogue of the Entire and Inestimable Apparatus for Lectures in Midwifery… by the Late Ingenious Dr. William Smellie, Deceased.” Eighteenth Century British Midwifery. Ed. Pam Lieske. (London: Pickering and Chatto), p. 96.
